title: Case Study: Spastic Diplegic Cerebral Palsy in a 10-year-old Male
clinical_history: A 10-year-old male with a diagnosis of spastic diplegic cerebral palsy presents with increased tone and stiffness in his lower extremities, particularly in the adductor and hamstring muscle groups. He experiences difficulty with ambulation, often requiring the use of a walker for support. The patient has a history of frequent falls and has difficulty with transfers. He also experiences pain and stiffness in his lower back and hips.

nprs.affected_area: Bilateral lower extremity stiffness and pain, more pronounced in the adductor and hamstring muscle groups

aggrevating_factors: Prolonged standing, walking, or sitting; changes in weather; fatigue
picture: A 24-hour picture of the patient's daily activities, including morning stiffness, difficulty with transfers, and use of a walker for ambulation
easing_factors: Physical therapy, stretching exercises, use of orthotics
past_history: The patient was born prematurely at 28 weeks gestation and required a prolonged stay in the NICU. He was diagnosed with cerebral palsy at 2 years of age.
medical_history: The patient has a history of constipation, gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), and seizures, which are well-controlled with medication.
medications: Baclofen for muscle spasticity, omeprazole for GERD, and carbamazepine for seizures
personal_history: The patient lives with his family and attends a special education program. He requires assistance with activities of daily living, including dressing, grooming, and feeding.
imaging: X-rays of the pelvis and lower extremities show mild hip dysplasia and genu valgum.
